intro: Pappostipa speciosa var. breviglumis, commonly known as the short-glume bluegrass, is a perennial grass native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its slender, tufted growth habit and narrow, bluish-green leaves. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear tiny, wind-dispersed seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and wetland restoration projects.
